title: Nature's mood rings: How chameleons really change color

multiple-choice.question: What is one thing that chameleons do when they feel threatened or annoyed?

options.label: A
options.text: They hide in their burrows.

options.label: B
options.text: They change color to match their environment.

options.label: C
options.text: They transform into living mood rings.

options.label: D
options.text: They become more aggressive.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why chameleons change color?

options.label: A
options.text: To blend in with their surroundings.

options.label: B
options.text: To show off their beauty.

options.label: C
options.text: To make a statement.

options.label: D
options.text: To communicate with other chameleons.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the cells called iridophores in a chameleon's skin?

options.label: A
options.text: They contain tiny, nano-scale salt crystals.

options.label: B
options.text: They are arranged in a two-dimensional lattice.

options.label: C
options.text: They are responsible for absorbing light.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only found in certain species of chameleons.

multiple-choice.question: What are electrical engineers at UC Berkeley trying to create?

options.label: A
options.text: A material that can change from one color to another.

options.label: B
options.text: A device that can mimic a chameleon's color-changing ability.

options.label: C
options.text: A synthetic version of a chameleon's skin.

options.label: D
options.text: A machine that can change the color of objects.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the color-changing ability of chameleons compared to other animals?

options.label: A
options.text: They can change color in a split second.

options.label: B
options.text: They can change color in response to their emotions.

options.label: C
options.text: They can produce colors that aren't even visible to human eyes.

options.label: D
options.text: They can only change color in response to their environment.

title: Why does February only have 28 days?

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with creating the original Roman calendar that had ten months of either 30 or 31 days?

options.label: A
options.text: Romulus

options.label: B
options.text: Numa Pompilius

options.label: C
options.text: Julius Caesar

options.label: D
options.text: Augustus Caesar

multiple-choice.question: Why did the Romans initially use a lunar calendar instead of a solar calendar?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was more accurate

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was easier to track the passage of time

options.label: C
options.text: Because it was a gift from the gods

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was a way to keep track of festivals and feasts

multiple-choice.question: What was the problem with Numa Pompilius's calendar, which had 355 days and was rounded up to 12 cycles of the moon?

options.label: A
options.text: It had too many even-numbered months

options.label: B
options.text: It had too many odd-numbered months

options.label: C
options.text: It had too many days in a year

options.label: D
options.text: It had an even number of days in a year

multiple-choice.question: Why did Julius Caesar create a new solar calendar in 46 BC?

options.label: A
options.text: Because he wanted to extend his term as king

options.label: B
options.text: Because he wanted to reform the calendar and make it more accurate

options.label: C
options.text: Because he wanted to rename the months after himself and his successor

options.label: D
options.text: Because he wanted to add more days to the year

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the calendar system was confusing and led to the creation of a new solar calendar?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the complexity of the lunar calendar

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the lack of accuracy in the solar calendar

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the frequent changes to the calendar system

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the addition of leap months

options.text: Pacific Ocean

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: 36,000 feet

options.label: D
options.text: 50,000 feet

options.label: C

options.label: A

title: The science of laziness

multiple-choice.question: Why do some people struggle with the desire for physical activity, despite it being an essential part of human biology?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are genetically predisposed to laziness.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are addicted to food and sex.

options.label: C
options.text: Because their brains are not wired to respond positively to natural rewards.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they lack the motivation to engage in physical activity.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the Gene that regulates activity levels and is responsible for a type of dopamine receptor?

options.label: A
options.text: The Couch Potato Gene

options.label: B
options.text: The Activity Gene

options.label: C
options.text: The Dopamine Receptor Gene

options.label: D
options.text: The Motivation Gene

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between the brains of running mice and those that chose not to run as much?

options.label: A
options.text: The running mice had smaller dopamine systems.

options.label: B
options.text: The running mice had larger dopamine systems and regions that deal with motivation and reward.

options.label: C
options.text: The running mice had the same dopamine systems as the non-running mice.

options.label: D
options.text: The running mice had a different type of dopamine receptor.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the brains of mice that are genetically addicted to running when they are deprived of activity?

options.label: A
options.text: They react similar to a healthy rodent.

options.label: B
options.text: They react similar to a rodent that is addicted to cocaine or nicotine.

options.label: C
options.text: They do not react at all.

options.label: D
options.text: They react with anxiety.

multiple-choice.question: What is one environmental mental factor that can contribute to physical laziness?

options.label: A
options.text: Genetics

options.label: B
options.text: Environment

options.label: C
options.text: Mental factors

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

title: Why does everyone hate pigeons?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why pigeons were able to conquer all of Earth's urban areas?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they were able to adapt to different climates.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they were able to fly faster than other birds.

options.label: C
options.text: Because humans brought them there and liked feeding them.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they were able to build their own homes.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about a pigeon's brain compared to other birds?

options.label: A
options.text: It is larger than other birds.

options.label: B
options.text: It is smaller than other birds.

options.label: C
options.text: It is only about the size of a fingertip.

options.label: D
options.text: It is shaped like a sphere.

multiple-choice.question: What is special about a pigeon's eyes compared to humans?

options.label: A
options.text: They have two color receptors.

options.label: B
options.text: They have five color receptors.

options.label: C
options.text: They have three color receptors.

options.label: D
options.text: They have no color receptors.

options.label: A
options.text: He tried to train them to fly faster.

options.label: B
options.text: He tried to train them to navigate using visual maps.

options.label: C
options.text: He tried to turn them into weapons by training them to keep an image centered on a tiny screen.

options.label: D
options.text: He tried to train them to build their own homes.

multiple-choice.question: What is one thing that pigeons are good at finding their way home from places they've never been?

options.label: A
options.text: Their food.

options.label: B
options.text: Their predators.

options.label: C
options.text: Their visual maps.

options.label: D
options.text: Their sense of smell.

title: How do pelicans survive their death-defying dives?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary way a brown pelican catches fish?

options.label: A
options.text: By using its powerful legs to kick the water.

options.label: B
options.text: By using its sword-shaped bill to slice into the surface of the water.

options.label: C
options.text: By diving downward at 40 miles an hour and then catching the fish.

options.label: D
options.text: By using its wings to scoop up the fish.

multiple-choice.question: How do pelicans survive a 40-foot drop onto rock-hard water?

options.label: A
options.text: By using their powerful muscles to tense around their spine.

options.label: B
options.text: By using their special network of extra air sacs under their skin.

options.label: C
options.text: By using their sword-shaped bill to cushion the impact.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the gular pouch in a pelican?

options.label: A
options.text: To help the pelican breathe underwater.

options.label: B
options.text: To help the pelican slow down its impact when hitting the water.

options.label: C
options.text: To help the pelican catch more fish.

options.label: D
options.text: To help the pelican store extra food.

options.label: A
options.text: It can only open up and down.

options.label: B
options.text: It can only open sideways.

options.label: C
options.text: It is very rigid and cannot move.

options.label: D
options.text: It is very flexible and can open sideways.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the pneumatic foramina in a pelican?

options.label: A
options.text: To help the pelican breathe underwater.

options.label: B
options.text: To help the pelican store extra food.

options.label: C
options.text: To cushion the impact when the pelican hits the water.

options.label: D
options.text: To help the pelican slow down its impact when hitting the water.

title: Why do we wrinkle when wet?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why our fingers and toes wrinkle when immersed in water for longer than 10 minutes?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of osmosis caused by water passing into the dry outer layer of skin.

options.label: B
options.text: An active response of the nervous system to prolonged moisture.

options.label: C
options.text: A genetic disorder that affects the skin.

options.label: D
options.text: A side effect of certain medications.

multiple-choice.question: What is one possible evolutionary function of wrinkly skin?

options.label: A
options.text: To improve our vision in low light conditions.

options.label: B
options.text: To give our ancestors a better grip while working in wet conditions.

options.label: C
options.text: To increase our body temperature in cold environments.

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce our sensitivity to pain.

multiple-choice.question: What did a 2013 study find when comparing subjects with wrinkly and non-wrinkly fingers?

options.label: A
options.text: That wrinkly fingers were slower at picking up wet objects.

options.label: B
options.text: That wrinkly fingers were faster at picking up wet objects.

options.label: C
options.text: That wrinkly fingers were better at picking up dry objects.

options.label: D
options.text: That wrinkly fingers had no effect on object-picking speed.

multiple-choice.question: Why isn't our skin wrinkly all of the time?

options.label: A
options.text: Because wrinkly skin is less attractive to potential mates.

options.label: B
options.text: Because wrinkly skin is less sensitive, which is no advantage at all.

options.label: C
options.text: Because wrinkly skin is more prone to injury.

options.label: D
options.text: Because wrinkly skin is more expensive to maintain.

title: How soap kills the coronavirus

multiple-choice.question: Why does soap effectively destroy the coronavirus?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it has antibacterial properties.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it dissolves the protein coating of the virus.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it pulls apart the fatty layer that holds the virus together.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a high concentration of alcohol.

options.label: C
options.text: 20 seconds

options.label: D
options.text: 30 seconds

options.text: At least 60% alcohol

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: No

options.text: It depends on the situation

options.label: D
options.text: It's not effective at all

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Because soap is harder to find than hand sanitizer.

title: Why don't we throw trash in volcanoes?

multiple-choice.question: Why is using volcanoes as a garbage disposal not a practical solution?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Because it would create a lot of noise pollution.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it would attract pests and rodents.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's hard to predict the weather.

options.label: A
options.text: It would create a lot of greenhouse gas emissions.

options.label: B
options.text: It would produce toxic fumes.

options.label: C
options.text: It would create a fire hazard.

options.label: D
options.text: It would make the air smell bad.

multiple-choice.question: Why should we not use volcanoes as a garbage disposal?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's not a sustainable solution.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's not a safe solution.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's not a cost-effective solution.

title: The white lie we've been told about Roman statues

multiple-choice.question: What was the original appearance of the statue of Augustus of Prima Porta, and why was it altered?

options.label: A
options.text: It was originally a vibrant, colorful statue, but it was altered to make it look more like the modern white marble statues of the Renaissance.

options.label: B
options.text: It was originally a white marble statue, but it was altered to make it look more colorful and lifelike.

options.label: C
options.text: It was originally a gray statue, but it was altered to make it look more vibrant and colorful.

options.label: D
options.text: It was originally a colorful statue, but it was altered to make it look more like the modern sculptures of the 20th century.

multiple-choice.question: What was the reason behind the widespread adoption of white marble as the norm in sculpture during the Renaissance?

options.label: A
options.text: Because white marble was the most readily available material at the time.

options.label: B
options.text: Because artists like Michelangelo fell in love with the lifelike figures and pristine white surface of ancient Roman sculptures.

options.label: C
options.text: Because historians like Johann Joaquin Vinkle Minh argued that statues like the Apollo of Belvedere were the epitome of beauty because the wider the body is the more beautiful it is.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was the preferred choice of the wealthy patrons who commissioned the sculptures.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the rediscovery of the ancient Roman city of Pompeii in the 1700s?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to the discovery of many new, previously unknown sculptures.

options.label: B
options.text: It provided evidence of the widespread use of colored marble in ancient Roman sculpture.

options.label: C
options.text: It led to the development of new techniques for preserving and restoring ancient sculptures.

options.label: D
options.text: It had no significant impact on the field of art history.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the tools used by scientists to reconstruct the original colors of ancient sculptures?

options.label: A
options.text: Ultraviolet light

options.label: B
options.text: X-ray technology

options.label: C
options.text: 3D scanning

options.label: D
options.text: DNA analysis

multiple-choice.question: Why do conservationists use 3D scanners to create plaster replicas of ancient sculptures?

options.label: A
options.text: To preserve the original sculpture for future generations.

options.label: B
options.text: To create more accurate replicas of the sculpture than can be achieved through traditional methods.

options.label: C
options.text: To make it easier to transport and display the sculpture.

options.label: D
options.text: To create more colorful versions of the sculpture.

title: Why parrots can talk like humans

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: The coronavirus explained and how you can combat it

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary way that the Corona virus spreads?

options.label: B
options.text: Through contact with contaminated surfaces

options.label: C
options.text: Through droplet infection when people cough

options.label: D
options.text: Through vector-borne transmission

options.label: B
options.text: The cells are destroyed, and the lungs' protective lining is gone

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The cells are not affected by the virus

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: By washing your hands regularly

options.label: C
options.text: By practicing social distancing

options.label: D
options.text: By ignoring the virus and doing nothing

options.label: A
options.text: A fast pandemic spreads quickly, while a slow pandemic spreads slowly

options.label: B
options.text: A fast pandemic is more contagious, while a slow pandemic is less contagious

options.label: C
options.text: A fast pandemic causes more deaths, while a slow pandemic causes fewer deaths

options.label: D
options.text: A fast pandemic starts with a rapid rate of infection, while a slow pandemic starts with a slow rate of infection

title: How a case gets to the US Supreme Court

multiple-choice.question: How many cases are submitted to the Supreme Court each year, but only 80 are accepted?
What is the name of the written request asking the Supreme Court to hear a case, which is usually shortened to "the writ of cert"?

options.label: A
options.text: Petition for a writ of certiorari

options.label: B
options.text: Petition for a writ of cert

options.label: C
options.text: Request for a writ of cert

options.label: D
options.text: Application for a writ of cert

multiple-choice.question: What is the "rule of four" that determines whether a petition for a writ of cert is granted?

options.label: A
options.text: The rule that four justices must agree on the decision

options.label: B
options.text: The rule that four justices must be present in the courtroom

options.label: C
options.text: The rule that four justices must want to hear the case

options.label: D
options.text: The rule that four justices must agree on the petition

multiple-choice.question: What type of case is "Gonsalez v. Raich", in which the Supreme Court established the authority of federal law prohibiting the use of medical marijuana?

options.label: A
options.text: A case of national importance

options.label: B
options.text: A case in which a lower court issues a ruling that invalidates federal law

options.label: C
options.text: A case in which a lower court issues a ruling that upholds federal law

options.label: D
options.text: A case in which a lower court issues a ruling that is consistent with federal law

multiple-choice.question: What happened in the case "Obergefell v. Hodges", which was a case that the Supreme Court accepted to resolve a split decision in the lower courts?

options.label: A
options.text: The court ruled that same-sex marriage was not a right nationwide

options.label: B
options.text: The court ruled that same-sex marriage was a right nationwide

options.label: C
options.text: The court ruled that same-sex marriage was a right in Ohio but not nationwide

options.label: D
options.text: The court ruled that same-sex marriage was not a right in Ohio but nationwide

title: Do we own the land?

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the traditional Aboriginal way of viewing land ownership?

options.label: A
options.text: The land is owned by humans.

options.label: B
options.text: The land is owned by the government.

options.label: C
options.text: The land owns us, and we are responsible for caring for it.

options.label: D

title: The terrifying truth about bananas

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the bananas that you see at the store?

options.label: A
options.text: They are native to North America.

options.label: B
options.text: They are genetically identical.

options.label: C
options.text: They are a type of fruit that grows on trees.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a type of vegetable that grows underground.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for the decline of the Gros Michel banana variety?

options.label: A
options.text: It was too sweet and people didn't like it.

options.label: B
options.text: It was too big and people didn't like it.

options.label: C
options.text: A fungicide-resistant pathogen called the Panama disease began infecting the crop.

options.label: D
options.text: It was too expensive and people couldn't afford it.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main concern about the Cavendish banana variety?

options.label: A
options.text: It is too expensive to produce.

options.label: B
options.text: It is not healthy for people to eat.

options.label: C
options.text: A strain of Panama disease that affects the Cavendish strain has been identified.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not popular among consumers.

multiple-choice.question: How do scientists and growers plan to protect the Cavendish banana variety?

options.label: A
options.text: By creating genetically identical bananas.

options.label: B
options.text: By genetically engineering Cavendish plants with immunity to Panama disease.

options.label: C
options.text: By destroying infected fields and growing new crops from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock.

options.label: D
options.text: By all of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What did scientists learn from the Gros Michel debacle?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of genetic diversity in crops.

options.label: B
options.text: The need for more expensive farming practices.

options.label: C
options.text: The value of quickly destroying infected fields and growing new crops from pathogen-free lab-grown plant stock.

options.label: D
options.text: The benefits of genetically engineering crops.
